segment.source: Driver Verifier Properties for Driver Package Projects
segment.target: Driver Verifier Properties for Driver Package Projects

segment.source: Driver Verifier is a run-time verification tool that increases the effectiveness of your driver testing.
segment.target: Driver Verifier is a run-time verification tool that increases the effectiveness of your driver testing.

segment.source: You can enable and configure Driver Verifier to run on all test computers when you deploy your driver for testing.
segment.target: You can enable and configure Driver Verifier to run on all test computers when you deploy your driver for testing.

segment.source: You should always set up a kernel mode debugging connection with the test computer when you enable Driver Verifier on the remote test computer.
segment.target: You should always set up a kernel mode debugging connection with the test computer when you enable Driver Verifier on the remote test computer.

segment.source: For information about configuring a target computer and setting up a debug cable, see [Setting Up Kernel-Mode Debugging in Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/hardware/hh439376.
segment.target: For information about configuring a target computer and setting up a debug cable, see [Setting Up Kernel-Mode Debugging in Visual Studio](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/hardware/hh439376.

segment.source: Setting Driver Verifier properties for driver package projects
segment.target: Setting Driver Verifier properties for driver package projects

segment.source: Open the property pages for your driver package.
segment.target: Open the property pages for your driver package.

segment.source: Right-click the driver package project in Solution Explorer and select Properties.
segment.target: Right-click the driver package project in Solution Explorer and select Properties.

segment.source: In the property pages for the driver package, click Configuration Properties, click Driver Install, and then click Driver Verification.
segment.target: In the property pages for the driver package, click Configuration Properties, click Driver Install, and then click Driver Verification.

segment.source: Select the Enable Driver Verification option.
segment.target: Select the Enable Driver Verification option.

segment.source: When this option is selected, you can select the driver or drivers to verify on the test computer and you can select the Driver Verifier options to use.
segment.target: When this option is selected, you can select the driver or drivers to verify on the test computer and you can select the Driver Verifier options to use.

segment.source: Project Configuration and Platform
segment.target: Project Configuration and Platform

segment.source: The configuration list and platform list let you apply different deployment settings for different project configuration and platform combinations.
segment.target: The configuration list and platform list let you apply different deployment settings for different project configuration and platform combinations.

segment.source: For example, you can deploy a driver to one test computer using a set of deployment options for debug builds and to a different test computer using deployment options for release builds.
segment.target: For example, you can deploy a driver to one test computer using a set of deployment options for debug builds and to a different test computer using deployment options for release builds.

segment.source: Enable Driver Verifier
segment.target: Enable Driver Verifier

segment.source: You can enable Driver Verifier on the test computer for all drivers on the computer, for the driver project only, or for a list of specified drivers.
segment.target: You can enable Driver Verifier on the test computer for all drivers on the computer, for the driver project only, or for a list of specified drivers.

segment.source: For example, you might want to enable Driver Verifier for the set of drivers on the stack for a particular device.
segment.target: For example, you might want to enable Driver Verifier for the set of drivers on the stack for a particular device.

segment.source: Verify Drivers
segment.target: Verify Drivers

segment.source: Specifies which driver or drivers to verify on the test computer.
segment.target: Specifies which driver or drivers to verify on the test computer.

segment.source: All Drivers
segment.target: All Drivers

segment.source: Specifies that Driver Verifier verifies all installed drivers on the remote test computer.
segment.target: Specifies that Driver Verifier verifies all installed drivers on the remote test computer.

segment.source: Project Output
segment.target: Project Output

segment.source: Specifies that Driver Verifier verifies the driver project installed on the remote test computer.
segment.target: Specifies that Driver Verifier verifies the driver project installed on the remote test computer.

segment.source: This is the default option.
segment.target: This is the default option.

segment.source: Driver List
segment.target: Driver List

segment.source: Specifies the driver or list of drivers that Driver Verifier verifies on the remote test computer.
segment.target: Specifies the driver or list of drivers that Driver Verifier verifies on the remote test computer.

segment.source: For example, you could list all of the drivers associated with a particular device.
segment.target: For example, you could list all of the drivers associated with a particular device.

segment.source: Specify the drivers by binary name, for example, Driver.sys.
segment.target: Specify the drivers by binary name, for example, Driver.sys.

segment.source: Use a semicolon to separate a list of drivers.
segment.target: Use a semicolon to separate a list of drivers.

segment.source: Wildcard values, such as n\*.sys, are not supported.
segment.target: Wildcard values, such as n\*.sys, are not supported.

segment.source: Driver Verifier Standard Flags
segment.target: Driver Verifier Standard Flags

segment.source: You can configure the following Driver Verifier options on the test computer.
segment.target: You can configure the following Driver Verifier options on the test computer.

segment.source: DDI compliance checking (Windows 8)
segment.target: DDI compliance checking (Windows 8)

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier applies a set of device driver interface (DDI) rules that check for the proper interaction between a driver and the kernel interface of the operating system.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier applies a set of device driver interface (DDI) rules that check for the proper interaction between a driver and the kernel interface of the operating system.

segment.source: Deadlock detection
segment.target: Deadlock detection

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier monitors the driver's use of spin locks, mutexes, and fast mutexes.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier monitors the driver's use of spin locks, mutexes, and fast mutexes.

segment.source: This detects whether the driver's code has the potential for causing a deadlock at some point.
segment.target: This detects whether the driver's code has the potential for causing a deadlock at some point.

segment.source: DMA verification
segment.target: DMA verification

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier monitors the driver's use of direct memory access (DMA) routines.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier monitors the driver's use of direct memory access (DMA) routines.

segment.source: This detects improper use of DMA buffers, adapters, and map registers.
segment.target: This detects improper use of DMA buffers, adapters, and map registers.

segment.source: Force IRQL checking
segment.target: Force IRQL checking

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier places extreme memory pressure on the driver by invalidating pageable code.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier places extreme memory pressure on the driver by invalidating pageable code.

segment.source: If the driver attempts to access paged memory at the wrong IRQL or while holding a spin lock, Driver Verifier detects this behavior.
segment.target: If the driver attempts to access paged memory at the wrong IRQL or while holding a spin lock, Driver Verifier detects this behavior.

segment.source: I/O verification
segment.target: I/O verification

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier allocates the driver's Interrupt Request Packets (IRPs) from a special pool, and monitors the driver's I/O handling.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier allocates the driver's Interrupt Request Packets (IRPs) from a special pool, and monitors the driver's I/O handling.

segment.source: This detects illegal or inconsistent use of I/O routines.
segment.target: This detects illegal or inconsistent use of I/O routines.

segment.source: Driver Verifier also monitors the calls of several I/O Manager routines and performs stress testing of Plug-and-Play (PnP) IRPs, power IRPs and WMI IRPs.
segment.target: Driver Verifier also monitors the calls of several I/O Manager routines and performs stress testing of Plug-and-Play (PnP) IRPs, power IRPs and WMI IRPs.

segment.source: Miscellaneous checks
segment.target: Miscellaneous checks

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier looks for common causes of driver crashes, such as the mishandling of freed memory.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier looks for common causes of driver crashes, such as the mishandling of freed memory.

segment.source: Pool tracking
segment.target: Pool tracking

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier checks to see whether the driver has freed all of its memory allocations when it is unloaded.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier checks to see whether the driver has freed all of its memory allocations when it is unloaded.

segment.source: This reveals memory leaks.
segment.target: This reveals memory leaks.

segment.source: Security checks
segment.target: Security checks

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier looks for common errors that can result in security vulnerabilities, such as a reference to user-mode addresses by kernel-mode routines.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier looks for common errors that can result in security vulnerabilities, such as a reference to user-mode addresses by kernel-mode routines.

segment.source: Special pool checking
segment.target: Special pool checking

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier allocates most of the driver's memory requests from a special pool.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier allocates most of the driver's memory requests from a special pool.

segment.source: This special pool is monitored for memory overruns, memory underruns, and memory that is accessed after it is freed.
segment.target: This special pool is monitored for memory overruns, memory underruns, and memory that is accessed after it is freed.

segment.source: Driver Verifier Scenario Specific Settings
segment.target: Driver Verifier Scenario Specific Settings

segment.source: Low resources simulation
segment.target: Low resources simulation

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier randomly fails pool allocation requests and other resource requests.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier randomly fails pool allocation requests and other resource requests.

segment.source: By injecting these allocation faults into the system, Driver Verifier tests the driver's ability to cope with a low-resource situation.
segment.target: By injecting these allocation faults into the system, Driver Verifier tests the driver's ability to cope with a low-resource situation.

segment.source: Force pending I/O requests
segment.target: Force pending I/O requests

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier tests the driver's response to STATUS\_PENDING return values by returning STATUS\_PENDING for random calls to IoCallDriver.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier tests the driver's response to STATUS\_PENDING return values by returning STATUS\_PENDING for random calls to IoCallDriver.

segment.source: IRP logging
segment.target: IRP logging

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier monitors a driver's use of IRPs and creates a log of IRP use.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier monitors a driver's use of IRPs and creates a log of IRP use.

segment.source: Invariant MDL Checking for Stack (Windows 8)
segment.target: Invariant MDL Checking for Stack (Windows 8)

segment.source: The Invariant MDL Checking for Stack option monitors how the driver handles invariant MDL buffers across the driver stack.
segment.target: The Invariant MDL Checking for Stack option monitors how the driver handles invariant MDL buffers across the driver stack.

segment.source: Driver Verifier can detect illegal modification of invariant MDL buffers.
segment.target: Driver Verifier can detect illegal modification of invariant MDL buffers.

segment.source: To use this option, I/O Verification must be enabled on at least one driver.
segment.target: To use this option, I/O Verification must be enabled on at least one driver.

segment.source: Invariant MDL Checking for Driver (Windows 8)
segment.target: Invariant MDL Checking for Driver (Windows 8)

segment.source: The Invariant MDL Checking for Driver option monitors how the driver handles invariant MDL buffers on a per-driver basis.
segment.target: The Invariant MDL Checking for Driver option monitors how the driver handles invariant MDL buffers on a per-driver basis.

segment.source: This option detects illegal modification of invariant MDL buffers.
segment.target: This option detects illegal modification of invariant MDL buffers.

segment.source: To use this option, you must enable I/O Verification on at least one driver.
segment.target: To use this option, you must enable I/O Verification on at least one driver.

segment.source: Power Framework Delay Fuzzing (Windows 8)
segment.target: Power Framework Delay Fuzzing (Windows 8)

segment.source: When this option is active, Driver Verifier randomizes thread schedules to help flush out concurrency errors in the driver.
segment.target: When this option is active, Driver Verifier randomizes thread schedules to help flush out concurrency errors in the driver.

segment.source: Stack Based Failure Injection (Windows 8)
segment.target: Stack Based Failure Injection (Windows 8)

segment.source: The Stack Based Failure Injection option injects resource failures in kernel-mode drivers.
segment.target: The Stack Based Failure Injection option injects resource failures in kernel-mode drivers.

segment.source: This option uses a special driver, KmAutoFail.sys, in conjunction with Driver Verifier to penetrate driver error handling paths.
segment.target: This option uses a special driver, KmAutoFail.sys, in conjunction with Driver Verifier to penetrate driver error handling paths.

segment.source: Note You cannot combine Stack Based Failure Injection with Low resources simulation.
segment.target: Note You cannot combine Stack Based Failure Injection with Low resources simulation.

segment.source: Driver Verifier options that require I/O Verification
segment.target: Driver Verifier options that require I/O Verification

segment.source: There are four options that require you to first enable I/O Verification.
segment.target: There are four options that require you to first enable I/O Verification.

segment.source: If I/O Verification is not enabled, these options are not enabled.
segment.target: If I/O Verification is not enabled, these options are not enabled.

segment.source: Force Pending I/O Requests
segment.target: Force Pending I/O Requests

segment.source: IRP Logging
segment.target: IRP Logging

segment.source: Invariant MDL Checking for Stack
segment.target: Invariant MDL Checking for Stack

segment.source: Invariant MDL Checking for Driver
segment.target: Invariant MDL Checking for Driver
